mn46:0.2.eng: The Great Discourse on Taking Up Practices

mn46:1.1.comm: The Buddha delves into this topic in more detail in MN 114.

mn46:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn46:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn46:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

mn46:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, sentient beings typically have the wish, desire, and hope:

mn46:2.2.pli: ‘aho vata aniṭṭhā akantā amanāpā dhammā parihāyeyyuṃ, iṭṭhā kantā manāpā dhammā abhivaḍḍheyyun’ti.
mn46:2.2.eng: ‘Oh, if only unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable things would decrease, and likable, desirable, and agreeable things would increase!’

mn46:2.3.pli: Tesaṃ, bhikkhave, sattānaṃ evaṅkāmānaṃ evaṃchandānaṃ evaṃadhippāyānaṃ aniṭṭhā akantā amanāpā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, iṭṭhā kantā manāpā dhammā parihāyanti.
mn46:2.3.eng: But exactly the opposite happens to them.

mn46:2.4.pli: Tatra tumhe, bhikkhave, kaṃ hetuṃ paccethā”ti?
mn46:2.4.eng: What do you take to be the reason for this?”

mn46:2.5.pli: “Bhagavaṃmūlakā no, bhante, dhammā, bhagavaṃnettikā, bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇā. Sādhu vata, bhante, bhagavantaññeva paṭibhātu etassa bhāsitassa attho; bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
mn46:2.5.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

mn46:2.6.pli: “Tena hi, bhikkhave, suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
mn46:2.6.eng: “Well then, mendicants, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

mn46:2.7.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

mn46:3.1.pli: “Idha, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano, ariyānaṃ adassāvī ariyadhammassa akovido ariyadhamme avinīto, sappurisānaṃ adassāvī sappurisadhammassa akovido sappurisadhamme avinīto,
mn46:3.1.eng: “Take an unlearned ordinary person who has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen true persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the true persons.

mn46:3.2.pli: sevitabbe dhamme na jānāti asevitabbe dhamme na jānāti, bhajitabbe dhamme na jānāti abhajitabbe dhamme na jānāti.
mn46:3.2.eng: They don’t know what practices they should cultivate and foster, and what practices they shouldn’t cultivate and foster.

mn46:3.3.pli: So sevitabbe dhamme ajānanto asevitabbe dhamme ajānanto, bhajitabbe dhamme ajānanto abhajitabbe dhamme ajānanto, asevitabbe dhamme sevati sevitabbe dhamme na sevati, abhajitabbe dhamme bhajati bhajitabbe dhamme na bhajati.
mn46:3.3.eng: So they cultivate and foster practices they shouldn’t, and don’t cultivate and foster practices they should.

mn46:3.4.pli: Tassa asevitabbe dhamme sevato sevitabbe dhamme asevato, abhajitabbe dhamme bhajato bhajitabbe dhamme abhajato aniṭṭhā akantā amanāpā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, iṭṭhā kantā manāpā dhammā parihāyanti.
mn46:3.4.eng: When they do so, unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable things increase, and likable, desirable, and agreeable things decrease.

mn46:3.6.pli: Evañhetaṃ, bhikkhave, hoti yathā taṃ aviddasuno.
mn46:3.6.eng: Because that’s what it’s like for someone who doesn’t know.

mn46:4.1.pli: Sutavā ca kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako, ariyānaṃ dassāvī ariyadhammassa kovido ariyadhamme suvinīto, sappurisānaṃ dassāvī sappurisadhammassa kovido sappurisadhamme suvinīto,
mn46:4.1.eng: But a learned noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen true persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the true persons.

mn46:4.2.pli: sevitabbe dhamme jānāti asevitabbe dhamme jānāti, bhajitabbe dhamme jānāti abhajitabbe dhamme jānāti.
mn46:4.2.eng: They know what practices they should cultivate and foster, and what practices they shouldn’t cultivate and foster.

mn46:4.3.pli: So sevitabbe dhamme jānanto asevitabbe dhamme jānanto, bhajitabbe dhamme jānanto abhajitabbe dhamme jānanto, asevitabbe dhamme na sevati sevitabbe dhamme sevati, abhajitabbe dhamme na bhajati bhajitabbe dhamme bhajati.
mn46:4.3.eng: So they cultivate and foster practices they should, and don’t cultivate and foster practices they shouldn’t.

mn46:4.4.pli: Tassa asevitabbe dhamme asevato sevitabbe dhamme sevato, abhajitabbe dhamme abhajato bhajitabbe dhamme bhajato, aniṭṭhā akantā amanāpā dhammā parihāyanti, iṭṭhā kantā manāpā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.
mn46:4.4.eng: When they do so, unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable things decrease, and likable, desirable, and agreeable things increase.

mn46:4.6.pli: Evañhetaṃ, bhikkhave, hoti yathā taṃ viddasuno.
mn46:4.6.eng: Because that’s what it’s like for someone who knows.

mn46:5.1.eng: Mendicants, there are these four ways of taking up practices.

mn46:5.3.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṃ paccuppannadukkhañceva āyatiñca dukkhavipākaṃ;
mn46:5.3.eng: There is a way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain.

mn46:5.4.pli: atthi, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṃ paccuppannasukhaṃ āyatiṃ dukkhavipākaṃ;
mn46:5.4.eng: There is a way of taking up practices that is pleasant now but results in future pain.

mn46:5.5.pli: atthi, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṃ paccuppannadukkhaṃ āyatiṃ sukhavipākaṃ;
mn46:5.5.eng: There is a way of taking up practices that is painful now but results in future pleasure.

mn46:5.6.pli: atthi, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṃ paccuppannasukhañceva āyatiñca sukhavipākaṃ.
mn46:5.6.eng: There is a way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure.

mn46:6.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yamidaṃ dhammasamādānaṃ paccuppannadukkhañceva āyatiñca dukkhavipākaṃ, taṃ avidvā avijjāgato yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti:
mn46:6.1.eng: When it comes to the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain, an ignoramus, without knowing this, doesn’t truly understand:

mn46:6.2.eng: ‘This is the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain.’

mn46:6.3.pli: Taṃ avidvā avijjāgato yathābhūtaṃ appajānanto taṃ sevati, taṃ na parivajjeti.
mn46:6.3.eng: So instead of avoiding that practice, they cultivate it.

mn46:6.4.pli: Tassa taṃ sevato, taṃ aparivajjayato, aniṭṭhā akantā amanāpā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, iṭṭhā kantā manāpā dhammā parihāyanti.
mn46:6.4.eng: When they do so, unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable things increase, and likable, desirable, and agreeable things decrease.

mn46:6.6.pli: Evañhetaṃ, bhikkhave, hoti yathā taṃ aviddasuno.
mn46:6.6.eng: Because that’s what it’s like for someone who doesn’t know.

mn46:7.6.pli: Evañhetaṃ, bhikkhave, hoti yathā taṃ aviddasuno.

mn46:10.1.eng: When it comes to the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain, a wise person, knowing this, truly understands:

mn46:10.2.eng: ‘This is the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain.’

mn46:10.3.pli: Taṃ vidvā vijjāgato yathābhūtaṃ pajānanto taṃ na sevati, taṃ parivajjeti.
mn46:10.3.eng: So instead of cultivating that practice, they avoid it.

mn46:10.4.pli: Tassa taṃ asevato, taṃ parivajjayato, aniṭṭhā akantā amanāpā dhammā parihāyanti, iṭṭhā kantā manāpā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.
mn46:10.4.eng: When they do so, unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable things decrease, and likable, desirable, and agreeable things increase.

mn46:10.6.pli: Evañhetaṃ, bhikkhave, hoti yathā taṃ viddasuno.

mn46:13.4.pli: Tassa taṃ sevato, taṃ aparivajjayato, aniṭṭhā akantā amanāpā dhammā parihāyanti, iṭṭhā kantā manāpā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.
mn46:13.4.eng: When they do so, unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable things decrease, and likable, desirable, and agreeable things increase.

mn46:14.1.pli: Katamañca, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṃ paccuppannadukkhañceva āyatiñca dukkhavipākaṃ?
mn46:14.1.eng: And what is the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain?

mn46:14.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena pāṇātipātī hoti, pāṇātipātapaccayā ca dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;
mn46:14.2.eng: It’s when someone in pain and sadness kills living creatures, steals, and commits sexual misconduct. They use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re covetous, malicious, with wrong view. Because of these things they experience pain and sadness.

mn46:14.3.pli: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena adinnādāyī hoti, adinnādānapaccayā ca dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:14.4.pli: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena kāmesu micchācārī hoti, kāmesu micchācārapaccayā ca dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:14.5.pli: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena musāvādī hoti, musāvādapaccayā ca dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:14.6.pli: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena pisuṇavāco hoti, pisuṇavācāpaccayā ca dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:14.7.pli: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena pharusavāco hoti, pharusavācāpaccayā ca dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:14.8.pli: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena samphappalāpī hoti, samphappalāpapaccayā ca dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:14.9.pli: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena abhijjhālu hoti, abhijjhāpaccayā ca dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:14.10.pli: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena byāpannacitto hoti, byāpādapaccayā ca dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:14.11.pli: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena micchādiṭṭhi hoti, micchādiṭṭhipaccayā ca dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.

mn46:14.12.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
mn46:14.12.eng: And when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

mn46:14.13.pli: Idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṃ paccuppannadukkhañceva āyatiñca dukkhavipākaṃ.
mn46:14.13.eng: This is called the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain.

mn46:15.1.pli: Katamañca, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṃ paccuppannasukhaṃ āyatiṃ dukkhavipākaṃ?
mn46:15.1.eng: And what is the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now but results in future pain?

mn46:15.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco sahāpi sukhena sahāpi somanassena pāṇātipātī hoti, pāṇātipātapaccayā ca sukhaṃ somanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;
mn46:15.2.eng: It’s when someone with pleasure and happiness kills living creatures, steals, and commits sexual misconduct. They use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re covetous, malicious, with wrong view. Because of these things they experience pleasure and happiness.

mn46:15.3.pli: sahāpi sukhena sahāpi somanassena adinnādāyī hoti, adinnādānapaccayā ca sukhaṃ somanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:15.4.pli: sahāpi sukhena sahāpi somanassena kāmesumicchācārī hoti, kāmesumicchācārapaccayā ca sukhaṃ somanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:15.5.pli: sahāpi sukhena sahāpi somanassena musāvādī hoti, musāvādapaccayā ca sukhaṃ somanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:15.6.pli: sahāpi sukhena sahāpi somanassena pisuṇavāco hoti, pisuṇavācāpaccayā ca sukhaṃ somanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:15.7.pli: sahāpi sukhena sahāpi somanassena pharusavāco hoti, pharusavācāpaccayā ca sukhaṃ somanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:15.8.pli: sahāpi sukhena sahāpi somanassena samphappalāpī hoti, samphappalāpapaccayā ca sukhaṃ somanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:15.9.pli: sahāpi sukhena sahāpi somanassena abhijjhālu hoti, abhijjhāpaccayā ca sukhaṃ somanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:15.10.pli: sahāpi sukhena sahāpi somanassena byāpannacitto hoti, byāpādapaccayā ca sukhaṃ somanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:15.11.pli: sahāpi sukhena sahāpi somanassena micchādiṭṭhi hoti, micchādiṭṭhipaccayā ca sukhaṃ somanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.

mn46:15.12.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
mn46:15.12.eng: But when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

mn46:15.13.pli: Idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṃ paccuppannasukhaṃ āyatiṃ dukkhavipākaṃ.
mn46:15.13.eng: This is called the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now but results in future pain.

mn46:16.1.pli: Katamañca, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṃ paccuppannadukkhaṃ āyatiṃ sukhavipākaṃ?
mn46:16.1.eng: And what is the way of taking up practices that is painful now but results in future pleasure?

mn46:16.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, pāṇātipātā veramaṇīpaccayā ca dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;
mn46:16.2.eng: It’s when someone in pain and sadness doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, or commit sexual misconduct. They don’t use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re contented, kind-hearted, with right view. Because of these things they experience pain and sadness.

mn46:16.3.pli: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti, adinnādānā veramaṇīpaccayā ca dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:16.4.pli: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato hoti, kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇīpaccayā ca dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:16.5.pli: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena musāvādā paṭivirato hoti, musāvādā veramaṇīpaccayā ca dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:16.6.pli: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, pisuṇāya vācāya veramaṇīpaccayā ca dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:16.7.pli: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, pharusāya vācāya veramaṇīpaccayā ca dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:16.8.pli: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti, samphappalāpā veramaṇīpaccayā ca dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:16.9.pli: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena anabhijjhālu hoti, anabhijjhāpaccayā ca dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:16.10.pli: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena abyāpannacitto hoti, abyāpādapaccayā ca dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:16.11.pli: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena sammādiṭṭhi hoti, sammādiṭṭhipaccayā ca dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.

mn46:16.12.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
mn46:16.12.eng: But when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

mn46:16.13.pli: Idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṃ paccuppannadukkhaṃ āyatiṃ sukhavipākaṃ.
mn46:16.13.eng: This is called the way of taking up practices that is painful now but results in future pleasure.

mn46:17.1.pli: Katamañca, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṃ paccuppannasukhañceva āyatiñca sukhavipākaṃ?
mn46:17.1.eng: And what is the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure?

mn46:17.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco sahāpi sukhena sahāpi somanassena pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, pāṇātipātā veramaṇīpaccayā ca sukhaṃ somanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;
mn46:17.2.eng: It’s when someone with pleasure and happiness doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, or commit sexual misconduct. They don’t use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re contented, kind-hearted, with right view. Because of these things they experience pleasure and happiness.

mn46:17.3.pli: sahāpi sukhena sahāpi somanassena adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti, adinnādānā veramaṇīpaccayā ca sukhaṃ somanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:17.4.pli: sahāpi sukhena sahāpi somanassena kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato hoti, kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇīpaccayā ca sukhaṃ somanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:17.5.pli: sahāpi sukhena sahāpi somanassena musāvādā paṭivirato hoti, musāvādā veramaṇīpaccayā ca sukhaṃ somanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:17.6.pli: sahāpi sukhena sahāpi somanassena pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, pisuṇāya vācāya veramaṇīpaccayā ca sukhaṃ somanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:17.7.pli: sahāpi sukhena sahāpi somanassena pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, pharusāya vācāya veramaṇīpaccayā ca sukhaṃ somanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:17.8.pli: sahāpi sukhena sahāpi somanassena samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti, samphappalāpā veramaṇīpaccayā ca sukhaṃ somanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:17.9.pli: sahāpi sukhena sahāpi somanassena anabhijjhālu hoti, anabhijjhāpaccayā ca sukhaṃ somanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:17.10.pli: sahāpi sukhena sahāpi somanassena abyāpannacitto hoti, abyāpādapaccayā ca sukhaṃ somanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;

mn46:17.11.pli: sahāpi sukhena sahāpi somanassena sammādiṭṭhi hoti, sammādiṭṭhipaccayā ca sukhaṃ somanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.

mn46:17.12.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
mn46:17.12.eng: And when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

mn46:17.13.pli: Idaṃ, vuccati, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṃ paccuppannasukhañceva āyatiñca sukhavipākaṃ.
mn46:17.13.eng: This is called the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure.

mn46:17.14.eng: These are the four ways of taking up practices.

mn46:18.1.eng: Suppose there was some bitter gourd mixed with poison.

mn46:18.2.pli: Atha puriso āgaccheyya jīvitukāmo amaritukāmo sukhakāmo dukkhappaṭikūlo.
mn46:18.2.eng: Then a man would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain.

mn46:18.4.eng: ‘Here, worthy man, this is bitter gourd mixed with poison.

mn46:18.6.pli: Tassa te pivato ceva nacchādessati vaṇṇenapi gandhenapi rasenapi, pivitvā ca pana maraṇaṃ vā nigacchasi maraṇamattaṃ vā dukkhan’ti.
mn46:18.6.eng: If you drink it, the color, aroma, and flavor will be unappetizing, and it will result in death or deadly pain.’

mn46:18.7.eng: He wouldn’t put it down. Without reflection, he’d drink it.

mn46:18.8.pli: Tassa taṃ pivato ceva nacchādeyya vaṇṇenapi gandhenapi rasenapi, pivitvā ca pana maraṇaṃ vā nigaccheyya maraṇamattaṃ vā dukkhaṃ.
mn46:18.8.eng: The color, aroma, and flavor would be unappetizing, and it would result in death or deadly pain.

mn46:18.9.pli: Tathūpamāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imaṃ dhammasamādānaṃ vadāmi, yamidaṃ dhammasamādānaṃ paccuppannadukkhañceva āyatiñca dukkhavipākaṃ.
mn46:18.9.eng: This is comparable to the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain, I say.

mn46:19.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, āpānīyakaṃso vaṇṇasampanno gandhasampanno rasasampanno.
mn46:19.1.eng: Suppose there was a bronze goblet of beverage that had a nice color, aroma, and flavor.

mn46:19.2.eng: But it was mixed with poison.

mn46:19.3.pli: Atha puriso āgaccheyya jīvitukāmo amaritukāmo sukhakāmo dukkhappaṭikūlo.
mn46:19.3.eng: Then a man would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain.

mn46:19.5.pli: ‘ambho purisa, ayaṃ āpānīyakaṃso vaṇṇasampanno gandhasampanno rasasampanno.
mn46:19.5.eng: ‘Here, worthy man, this bronze goblet of beverage has a nice color, aroma, and flavor.

mn46:19.8.pli: Tassa te pivatohi kho chādessati vaṇṇenapi gandhenapi rasenapi, pivitvā ca pana maraṇaṃ vā nigacchasi maraṇamattaṃ vā dukkhan’ti.
mn46:19.8.eng: If you drink it, the color, aroma, and flavor will be appetizing, but it will result in death or deadly pain.’

mn46:19.9.eng: He wouldn’t put it down. Without reflection, he’d drink it.

mn46:19.10.pli: Tassa taṃ pivatohi kho chādeyya vaṇṇenapi gandhenapi rasenapi, pivitvā ca pana maraṇaṃ vā nigaccheyya maraṇamattaṃ vā dukkhaṃ.
mn46:19.10.eng: The color, aroma, and flavor would be appetizing, but it would result in death or deadly pain.

mn46:19.11.pli: Tathūpamāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imaṃ dhammasamādānaṃ vadāmi, yamidaṃ dhammasamādānaṃ paccuppannasukhaṃ āyatiṃ dukkhavipākaṃ.
mn46:19.11.eng: This is comparable to the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pain, I say.

mn46:20.1.eng: Suppose there was some rancid urine mixed with different medicines.
mn46:20.1.comm: Rancid urine was the worst of medicines, used when nothing better was available. Specifically, the Vinaya allows it as a purgative in the case of snakebite (Kd 6:14.6.4), and gives chebulic myrobalan soaked in cattle urine as a remedy for jaundice (Kd 6:14.7.9). Modern research has shown that urine, far from being a sterile cure-all, contains dangerous levels of bacterial pathogens, and has no medicinal value.

mn46:20.2.eng: Then a man with jaundice would come along.

mn46:20.4.pli: ‘ambho purisa, idaṃ pūtimuttaṃ nānābhesajjehi saṃsaṭṭhaṃ, sace ākaṅkhasi piva.
mn46:20.4.eng: ‘Here, worthy man, this is rancid urine mixed with different medicines. Drink it if you like.

mn46:20.5.pli: Tassa te pivatohi kho nacchādessati vaṇṇenapi gandhenapi rasenapi, pivitvā ca pana sukhī bhavissasī’ti.
mn46:20.5.eng: If you drink it, the color, aroma, and flavor will be unappetizing, but after drinking it you will be happy.’

mn46:20.6.eng: He wouldn’t put it down. After appraisal, he’d drink it.

mn46:20.7.pli: Tassa taṃ pivatohi kho nacchādeyya vaṇṇenapi gandhenapi rasenapi, pivitvā ca pana sukhī assa.
mn46:20.7.eng: The color, aroma, and flavor would be unappetizing, but after drinking it he would be happy.

mn46:20.8.pli: Tathūpamāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imaṃ dhammasamādānaṃ vadāmi, yamidaṃ dhammasamādānaṃ paccuppannadukkhaṃ āyatiṃ sukhavipākaṃ.
mn46:20.8.eng: This is comparable to the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pleasure, I say.

mn46:21.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dadhi ca madhu ca sappi ca phāṇitañca ekajjhaṃ saṃsaṭṭhaṃ.
mn46:21.1.eng: Suppose there was some curds, honey, ghee, and molasses all mixed together.

mn46:21.2.eng: Then a man with bloody dysentery would come along.

mn46:21.4.pli: ‘ambho purisa, idaṃ dadhi ca madhu ca sappi ca phāṇitañca ekajjhaṃ saṃsaṭṭhaṃ, sace ākaṅkhasi piva.
mn46:21.4.eng: ‘Here, worthy man, this is curds, honey, ghee, and molasses all mixed together. Drink it if you like.

mn46:21.5.pli: Tassa te pivato ceva chādessati vaṇṇenapi gandhenapi rasenapi, pivitvā ca pana sukhī bhavissasī’ti.
mn46:21.5.eng: If you drink it, the color, aroma, and flavor will be appetizing, and after drinking it you will be happy.’

mn46:21.6.eng: He wouldn’t put it down. After appraisal, he’d drink it.

mn46:21.7.pli: Tassa taṃ pivato ceva chādeyya vaṇṇenapi gandhenapi rasenapi, pivitvā ca pana sukhī assa.
mn46:21.7.eng: The color, aroma, and flavor would be appetizing, and after drinking it he would be happy.

mn46:21.8.pli: Tathūpamāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imaṃ dhammasamādānaṃ vadāmi, yamidaṃ dhammasamādānaṃ paccuppannasukhañceva āyatiñca sukhavipākaṃ.
mn46:21.8.eng: This is comparable to the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure, I say.

mn46:22.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, vassānaṃ pacchime māse saradasamaye viddhe vigatavalāhake deve ādicco nabhaṃ abbhussakkamāno sabbaṃ ākāsagataṃ tamagataṃ abhivihacca bhāsate ca tapate ca virocate ca;
mn46:22.1.eng: It’s like the last month of the rainy season, in autumn, when the heavens are sunny and cloudless. And as the sun is rising to the firmament, having dispelled all the darkness of space, it shines and glows and radiates.

mn46:22.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, yamidaṃ dhammasamādānaṃ paccuppannasukhañceva āyatiñca sukhavipākaṃ tadaññe puthusamaṇabrāhmaṇaparappavāde abhivihacca bhāsate ca tapate ca virocate cā”ti.
mn46:22.2.eng: In the same way, this way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure dispels the doctrines of the various other ascetics and brahmins as it shines and glows and radiates.”
mn46:22.2.comm: This text as well as MN 45:7.9 answer the question of what practice results in future happiness, and so do not consider awakening. It is surprising to see such bold praise for such a modest teaching. The Chinese parallels to these suttas have the inverse situation, as they describe a practice leading to non-return (MA 174 at T i 712b27) or Nibbana (MA 175 at T i 712c25, T 83 at T i 902c10), yet do not have this passage of praise.

mn46:22.3.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn46:22.4.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn46:22.4.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
